question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If no substitution is required, select ‘No substitution’.
After the old building w̲a̲s̲ ̲p̲u̲l̲l̲e̲d̲ ̲o̲u̲t̲, the building contractor surveyed the progress of the work.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 20 August Shift 1 (9 to 10 AM))
solution:
Answer: was pulled down
Solution:
• “Pulled down” correctly means demolished or torn down, which suits an old building being removed.

Why the other options are incorrect:
• was pulled up – means extracted or lifted out (e.g., a plant by its roots), not demolition.
• was pulled over – means caused to stop and move to the side (e.g., a vehicle by the police), irrelevant here.
• No substitution – incorrect, because “pulled out” doesn’t convey the idea of tearing down a structure.

Difficult words:
• contractor: a person or company that undertakes a contract to provide materials or labor; ठेकेदार
• surveyed: examined or inspected; निरीक्षण किया

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If no substitution is required, select ‘No substitution’.
Sunil h̲a̲v̲e̲ ̲b̲e̲e̲n̲ ̲w̲o̲r̲k̲i̲n̲g̲ as a personal assistant to the Director for two years.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 20 August Shift 2 (12 to 1 PM))
solution:
Answer: has been working
Solution:

  • Sunil is third person singular, so the correct present perfect continuous form is “has been working”, not “have been working.”

Why the other options are incorrect:

  • No substitution (कोई परिवर्तन नहीं) – Retains the original “have been working,” which is grammatically incorrect for thirdperson singular.

  • has been worked (काम किया गया है) – This is a passive construction, not the intended active continuous form.

  • is working (काम कर रहा है) – Present continuous tense describes an action only in progress now, not one continuing for two years.

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed select ‘No improvement required’.
He will lose all his wealth if he d̲o̲e̲s̲n̲'̲t̲ ̲m̲e̲n̲d̲s̲ his ways.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 20 August Shift 3 (3 to 4 PM))
solution:
Answer: doesn’t mend

Solution:

  • For thirdperson singular, English uses “doesn’t” plus the base form of the verb. So it must be “doesn’t mend”, not “doesn’t mends.”

Why the other options are incorrect:

  • No improvement required – would keep “doesn’t mends”, which is wrong because “doesn’t” must be followed by the base verb; (परिवर्तन आवश्यक नहीं)

  • do not mend – uses “do” instead of “does”, so it doesn’t agree with “he”; (संदर्भ: “देखता नहीं है”)

  • don’t mends – combines plural auxiliary “don’t” with a singular verb form “mends”, doubly incorrect; (“नहीं सुधारता”)

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed, select 'No improvement required'.
I don’t fancy t̲o̲ ̲g̲o̲ ̲o̲u̲t̲ this evening.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 21 Apr S3 (4 to 5 PM))
solution:
Explanation:

Error Type: Verb pattern – certain verbs are followed by gerunds (–ing forms) and not infinitives (to + verb).
Affected Part of Speech: Verb complement.
Rule:
Some verbs like "enjoy," "consider," "fancy," "avoid," etc. are followed by gerunds, not infinitives.

✔️ I fancy going out.
❌ I fancy to go out.

❌ Evaluation of Other Options:

  • to be going out – awkward and overly complex (बेकार जटिल रूप)

  • to going outside – grammatically wrong (infinitive + gerund का गलत मेल), and "outside" adds a physical direction that's unnecessary here

  • No improvement required – incorrect because the underlined usage is grammatically wrong

✅ Final Answer: going out

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution’.
My friend i̲s̲ ̲o̲w̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲a̲n̲ ̲e̲x̲p̲e̲n̲s̲i̲v̲e̲ ̲c̲e̲l̲l̲ ̲p̲h̲o̲n̲e̲.̲

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 21 July Shift-2)
option_1: owns an expensive cell phone.
option_3: is own an expensive cell phone
option_4: own an expensive cell phone
solution:
Answer:(1) owns an expensive cell phone.

Solution:
The original sentence "My friend is owing an expensive cell phone" is grammatically incorrect, because the verb “own” is a stative verb and should not be used in the continuous tense ("is owing").

Correct usage:
"My friend owns an expensive cell phone."

Other options:

  • No substitution – Incorrect, because "is owing" is wrong.

  • is own – Grammatically incorrect verb form.

  • own – Incorrect subject-verb agreement (needs "owns" with singular subject).

Word Meanings:

  • Own – मालिक होना

  • Expensive – महंगा

  • Cell phone – मोबाइल फोन

question:
Correct the sentence with the appropriate form of the underline verb.
Parents should tell their children to exercise great care when c̲r̲o̲s̲s̲e̲d̲ busy roads.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 21 July Shift-4)
solution:
Answer:(1) crossing

Solution:
The sentence requires the present participle form “crossing” after the verb "when" to indicate the action taking place.

Correct sentence:
Parents should tell their children to exercise great care when crossing busy roads.

Other options:

  • has crossed – Present perfect; incorrect after “when”.

  • has been crossing – Present perfect continuous; inappropriate here.

  • cross – Base form; incorrect after “when”.

Word Meanings:

  • Crossing – पार करना

  • Care – सावधानी

  • Busy roads – व्यस्त सड़कें

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If no substitution is required, select ‘No substitution’.
What were the examples that the writer g̲a̲v̲e̲ ̲t̲o̲ ̲p̲r̲o̲v̲e̲d̲ ̲h̲i̲s̲ ̲p̲o̲i̲n̲t̲?

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 23 August Shift 1 (9 to 10 AM))
option_1: give for proving his point
option_2: gave to prove his point
option_4: given to prove his point
solution:
Answer: gave to prove his point

Solution:
The original sentence uses the incorrect phrase "gave to proved", which is grammatically wrong because after "to", we must use the base form of the verb, not the past tense.
Correct structure: "gave to prove", where "gave" is the past tense of "give", and "to prove" is an infinitive used to express purpose.

Why the other options are incorrect:
• give for proving his point – Incorrect tense ("give" is present tense), and the phrase "for proving" is awkward and less idiomatic.
• No substitution – Incorrect because the original phrase contains a grammar error ("to proved").
• given to prove his point – "given" is a past participle and doesn't fit here without an auxiliary verb like "has/had been".

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If no substitution is required, select ‘No substitution’.
If you are not able to go out, d̲i̲d̲ ̲n̲o̲t̲ ̲w̲o̲r̲r̲y̲.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 23 August Shift 1 (9 to 10 AM))
solution:
Answer: do not worry

Solution:
The sentence is a conditional sentence starting with "If you are not able to go out" (present tense). So the second part should be in the imperative mood (giving advice or instruction), and the correct form is: "do not worry".

Correct sentence: "If you are not able to go out, do not worry."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
If only I̲ ̲w̲a̲s̲ ̲y̲o̲u̲n̲g̲ ̲a̲g̲a̲i̲n̲ .

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 24 July Shift-1)
option_3: I will be young again
solution:
Answer:(4) I were young again

Solution:
The sentence is a subjunctive mood expressing a hypothetical or unreal condition. In such cases, “were” is used instead of “was” for all subjects.

Correct sentence:
“If I were young again.”

Other options:

  • I be young again – Incorrect form.

  • I am young again – Present tense, not subjunctive.

  • I will be young again – Future tense, not subjunctive.

Word Meanings:

  • Subjunctive mood – काल्पनिक वाक्य रूप

  • Were – था/थी (काल्पनिक)

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
He d̲e̲s̲c̲r̲i̲b̲e̲d̲ ̲a̲b̲o̲u̲t̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲s̲c̲e̲n̲e̲r̲y̲ yesterday.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 27 July Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: described the scenery
Solution:

  • The verb describe does not require the preposition "about" after it.

  • The correct phrase is "described the scenery".

  • Also, the correct spelling is "scenery" not "scenary".

  • Other options contain grammatical errors or misspellings. ✅

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
I worked hard so t̲h̲a̲t̲ ̲I̲ ̲m̲i̲g̲h̲t̲ ̲s̲u̲c̲c̲e̲s̲s̲ .

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 27 July Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: that I might succeed

Solution:

  • The correct verb form to express achieving the goal is succeed (verb), not success (noun) or successor (person).

  • "Might" correctly expresses possibility or purpose.

  • So, "that I might succeed" is grammatically and contextually correct.

  • Other options misuse the noun or adjective forms or have wrong grammar.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Polyethylene terephthalate, one of the most often recycled plastics and the material used in the majority of water and soda bottles, c̲a̲n̲ ̲b̲e̲ ̲t̲r̲a̲n̲s̲f̲o̲r̲m̲e̲d̲ into everything from polyester fabric to automotive parts.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 27 July Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: a) may be converted

  • The underlined phrase is: "can be transformed"

  • It means “can be changed into another form or use” (किसी और रूप में बदला जा सकता है)

Option meanings with Hindi:

  • may be converted – can be changed into another form (बदला जा सकता है) ✔️closest in meaning

  • might be evolved – to gradually develop (विकसित होना) – doesn’t fit the idea of changing material

  • might be placed – to be put somewhere (रखा जा सकता है) – unrelated

  • may be devaluated – to reduce value (मूल्य घटाना) – opposite meaning

So, the best substitute for “can be transformed” is “may be converted”.

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence.
It is wrong to make accusations ̲without will have any proof̲.

(SSC SP Ph-11 : 27 June Shift-3)
option_2: without being have any proof
option_4: without to be have any proof
solution:
The option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence is: "without having any proof"

Without having any proof: This option is grammatically correct. "Having" is the correct verb form to use after "without" in this context. It indicates the absence of proof at the time of making accusations.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Oscar is the most prestigious award which is i̲n̲t̲r̲o̲d̲u̲c̲e̲d̲ ̲t̲o̲ ̲g̲o̲o̲d̲ actors in that year.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 3 Dec Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: awarded to best

Explanation:

  • The verb–noun collocation for giving an award is “award to” rather than “introduce to.”

  • “Best” correctly follows “the most prestigious award,” indicating the top actors of the year.

  • The other options are unidiomatic:

  • rewarded to good – reward, not award, and “good” is too general

  • attached to fine – doesn’t convey giving an award

  • nominated to fine – nomination precedes award and “to fine” is incorrect

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution’.
I like to read books, but my brother prefers t̲o̲ ̲w̲a̲t̲c̲h̲i̲n̲g̲ movies.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 3 Oct Shift-3 (4 to 6 PM))
solution:
The most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence is: to watch

In this context, "to watch" is the appropriate infinitive phrase that complements the verb "prefers" and conveys the intended meaning that the brother enjoys watching movies as his preference over reading books.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The volunteers of the organisation r̲e̲f̲u̲s̲e̲d̲ ̲p̲o̲i̲n̲t̲ ̲b̲l̲a̲n̲k̲ ̲o̲f̲ ̲d̲o̲ what was requested.

(SSC SP Ph-11 : 30 June Shift-1 )
option_1: refused point blank to do
option_2: refused point blankedly to do
option_3: refused in point blank of doing
solution:
The most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment "refused point blank of" in the given sentence is: refused point blank to do

The phrase "point blank" is an idiomatic expression meaning directly or bluntly. When used in this context, it indicates that the volunteers refused the request directly or without hesitation.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Naina is leaving and I am t̲h̲i̲n̲k̲ ̲t̲o̲ ̲a̲p̲p̲l̲y̲ for her job.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 4 Oct Shift-3 (4 to 6 PM))
solution:
The most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence is: "thinking about applying"
"thinking about applying": This option correctly uses the preposition "about" after "thinking," indicating consideration or contemplation. Additionally, "applying" is in the gerund form, which is appropriate in this context. This option expresses the intended meaning effectively.
So, the corrected sentence would be:

"Naina is leaving and I am thinking about applying for her job."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The airplane f̲l̲o̲w̲e̲d̲ ̲o̲v̲e̲r̲ the mountains, offering the passengers a breath-taking view of the majestic peaks below.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 4_Sept_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: 3
Solution: The correct substitution is "flew over".

  • "Flew over" is the appropriate phrase for an airplane moving above and across something (e.g., mountains).

  • "Flowed" is used for liquids or gases, not for airplanes.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • Flowed beyond ❌: incorrect verb for airplane and wrong preposition.

  • Flew beyond ❌: "beyond" means farther than, not above or across.

  • Flowed above ❌: incorrect verb.

Therefore, "flew over" is the correct and natural choice.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
They would find someone d̲r̲i̲v̲e̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ wagon back across the desert.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 4_Sept_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: 4
Solution: The correct phrase is "to drive the".

The sentence is:
"They would find someone to drive the wagon back across the desert."

Here, "to drive the" correctly introduces the infinitive verb phrase along with the direct object "wagon." The underlined segment is incomplete without "the" before "wagon," so adding "the" completes the phrase.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • in driving ❌: incorrect prepositional phrase here.

  • to drive ❌: incomplete because the object "wagon" follows, so "to drive the" is needed.

  • in drive in the ❌: grammatically incorrect.

Thus, "to drive the" is the correct and complete phrase.

Ask ChatGPT

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution required’.
H̲a̲v̲e̲ ̲y̲o̲u̲ ̲w̲a̲n̲t̲ ̲m̲e̲ to come with you to the dentist?

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 5 Dec Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: Do you want me

Explanation:

  • In questions about present wishes or requests, English uses do-support: Do you want me…?

  • “Have you want” is ungrammatical: “have” + past participle works for perfect tenses, not for simple present.

  • The other verb forms don’t fit the meaning or tense.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The art history teacher was sacked after s̲h̲e̲ ̲w̲e̲r̲e̲ ̲t̲h̲o̲u̲g̲h̲t̲ taking school supplies.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 5 Dec Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: she was caught

Explanation:

  • The original phrase “she were thought taking” is ungrammatical and awkward.

  • “She was caught” correctly conveys that she was found in the act of taking school supplies.

  • The other options don’t fit the context:

  • she was wondered – doesn’t make sense here

  • she was enlightened – means given knowledge

  • she was dumped – means thrown out or abandoned

Thus, she was caught is the most appropriate substitution.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution’.
Santa Claus stays at the North Pole when he isn’t o̲u̲t̲ ̲d̲e̲l̲i̲v̲e̲r̲ gifts for Christmas.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 5 Dec Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: out delivering

Explanation:
The sentence needs a present participle after “out” to describe the action Santa Claus is engaged in. “Out delivering gifts” correctly shows he is away performing that task.

  • out delivering – uses the participle “delivering” to indicate an ongoing action, which is exactly what Santa does when he’s not at the North Pole.

  • No substitution – would leave the original “out deliver,” which is ungrammatical (base form “deliver” cannot follow “out” in this context).

  • out to delivering – mixes infinitive marker “to” with a participle, which is incorrect.

  • out of deliver – nonsensical, as “of” plus base verb doesn’t form a valid verb phrase here.

Therefore, out delivering is the only grammatically and idiomatically correct choice.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Mother ordered John t̲o̲ ̲s̲w̲i̲t̲c̲h̲ ̲o̲n̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲l̲i̲g̲h̲t̲ as it was time to sleep.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 5 Dec Shift-4)
option_1: to switch off the light
option_2: to switch out the light
option_3: to switch of the light
option_4: to switch in the light
solution:
Answer: to switch off the light

Explanation:

  • The correct phrase is switch off the light (बत्ती बुझाना), which means to turn off the light.

  • The sentence makes sense because people usually turn off lights before sleeping.

  • The other options—switch out, switch of, switch in—are incorrect or unidiomatic in this context.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Mohan unknowingly a̲l̲t̲e̲r̲e̲d̲ ̲s̲a̲l̲t̲ ̲i̲n̲s̲t̲e̲a̲d̲ ̲o̲f̲ ̲s̲u̲g̲a̲r̲ to the dessert making it taste terrible.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 5_Sept_Shift-1)
option_1: added salt instead of sugar
option_2: amplified salt instead of sugar
option_3: anguished salt instead of sugar
option_4: abridged salt instead of sugar
solution:
Answer: Option 1 – added salt instead of sugar

Solution:

The original sentence is:
"Mohan unknowingly altered salt instead of sugar to the dessert making it taste terrible."

Let’s understand why this needs correction:

  • The verb “altered” means changed, but in this context, Mohan put salt in place of sugar, not modified salt itself.

  • So, the correct verb should indicate addition or substitution, not alteration.

Now examine the options:

  • Option 1 – added salt instead of sugar
    ✅ Correct and clear expression. It means salt was mistakenly used in place of sugar, which suits the context perfectly.

  • Option 2 – amplified salt instead of sugar
    ❌ “Amplified” means increased in volume or intensity (बढ़ाना), which is incorrect here.

  • Option 3 – anguished salt instead of sugar
    ❌ “Anguished” is an adjective/verb meaning to suffer emotionally (कष्ट पाना). Grammatically and contextually incorrect.

  • Option 4 – abridged salt instead of sugar
    ❌ “Abridged” means to shorten a text (संक्षिप्त करना), not relevant to food ingredients.

The best and grammatically appropriate substitute is:
added salt instead of sugar – Option 1.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
To p̲r̲e̲p̲a̲r̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲v̲i̲n̲e̲ ̲f̲o̲r̲ ̲p̲l̲a̲n̲t̲, it should be cut back to 2 ft.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 6_Sept_Shift-2)
option_1: prepare a vine in planting
option_2: prepared the vine of plant
option_3: prepare the vine for planting
option_4: prepares in vine in plant
solution:
Answer: (3) prepare the vine for planting
Solution:
• "To preparing" is incorrect – After the word "to", we must use the base form of the verb (infinitive), not the -ing form. So instead of "to preparing", it should be "to prepare"
• "for plant" is incorrect – The word "plant" is a noun, but here we need to show the action or process of planting, so the correct word is "planting" (a gerund)
• "prepare the vine for planting" is correct – It correctly uses the base verb "prepare" and the gerund "planting", making the phrase grammatically and contextually correct
• The full corrected sentence becomes – "To prepare the vine for planting, it should be cut back to 2 ft"
• Other options are grammatically incorrect or awkward in meaning, while option (3) is the only one that fits both structure and sense

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
They a̲r̲e̲ ̲s̲e̲l̲l̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲i̲r̲ ̲c̲o̲m̲p̲a̲n̲y̲’̲s̲ products to people.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 6_Sept_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: (4) are selling their company’s
Solution:
• The original phrase "are sell their company’s" is grammatically incorrect because after "are", we must use the present participle (verb + ing) form
• The correct verb form is "selling", not "sell"
• "Their company’s" is correct as it shows possession (the products belong to their company)
• So, the correct verb phrase is "are selling their company’s"

Correct sentence:
"They are selling their company’s products to people."

Other options explained:
• (1) are sell the company – wrong verb form and changes meaning
• (2) was sell the company’s – wrong tense and verb form
• (3) is selling they company’s – incorrect subject-verb agreement and wrong pronoun ("they" instead of "their")

Thus, the best substitution is (4) are selling their company’s.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to replace the underlined segment in the given sentence.
They s̲p̲o̲k̲e̲ about the political turmoil in the state.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 7 Dec Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: talked

Explanation:

  • Spoke about and talked about are equivalent phrasal verbs meaning discussed something (चर्चा की).

  • Said isn’t typically followed by about in this context.

  • Stated is more formal and normally takes a direct object without about (“stated the facts”).

  • Expressed usually pairs with feelings or opinions (“expressed concern”), not general discussion.

Thus, talked about the political turmoil is the most natural choice.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution’.
There are many people in the world w̲h̲o̲ ̲b̲e̲l̲i̲e̲v̲e̲ ̲t̲h̲a̲t̲ the earth is flat.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 7 Dec Shift-4)
solution:
Answer: No substitution

Explanation:
The original phrase “who believe that” correctly uses the present tense to match “are” and conveys the intended meaning. None of the other options fit grammatically or semantically:

  • who believed shifts to past tense,

  • who should believe that changes meaning,

  • who belief that is ungrammatical.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution’.
When I was your age, I was working two jobs t̲o̲ ̲p̲r̲o̲v̲i̲d̲e̲ ̲f̲o̲r̲ my family.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 8 Dec Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: No substitution

Explanation:

  • The infinitive “to provide for” correctly expresses purpose (“in order to support”).

  • “On providing” and “to providing for” are unidiomatic, and “for provide to” is incorrect.

  • Therefore, the original phrase needs no change.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Many companies d̲i̲s̲p̲l̲a̲c̲e̲d̲ ̲p̲a̲y̲i̲n̲g̲ income tax last year.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 8 Dec Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: evaded paying

Explanation:

  • Evaded means illegally avoided or kept away from (टालना), fitting the idea of dodging tax.

  • Displaced is incorrect—nothing is being moved.

  • “Hedged to/in paying” and “circumvent to paying” are unidiomatic.

Thus, “Many companies evaded paying income tax last year” is correct.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
He was not a̲b̲l̲e̲ ̲t̲o̲ ̲a̲d̲o̲p̲t̲ ̲h̲i̲m̲s̲e̲l̲f̲ ̲t̲o̲ the new environment of the hostel.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 9 Dec Shift-4)
option_1: able for adopt himself to
option_2: able to adopt himself with
option_3: able to adapt himself to
option_4: able to adept himself to
solution:
Answer: able to adapt himself to

Explanation:
The verb adapt means to adjust to new conditions, while adopt means to take up or choose something. Here, he must adjust himself to the hostel environment.

  • adapt = adjust (अनुकूलित करना)

  • adopt = take up (अपनाना)

  • Use to after adapt when referring to conditions.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The speaker i̲s̲ ̲a̲b̲o̲u̲t̲ ̲t̲o̲ ̲b̲e̲g̲i̲n̲n̲e̲r̲ his speech.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-1 : 9 Nov Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: 1 (is about to begin)

Solution:
The sentence is:
"The speaker is about to beginner his speech."
This is incorrect because “beginner” is a noun, while the sentence requires a verb.

The correct structure is:
“is about to + base verb”, and the base verb is “begin”.

✔ Correct sentence:
"The speaker is about to begin his speech."

Why other options are incorrect:

  • Was about to began – incorrect tense and “began” is past tense; not used after “to”.

  • Is about to beginning – incorrect form; “beginning” is a gerund/participle, not used after “to”.

  • Was about to beginner – again uses a noun instead of a verb.

Difficult Word Meaning:
Begin – to start (शुरू करना)
Beginner – a person new to something (नवशिक्षु)
